tossups.question: The entire 21st floor of the Gagosian Gallery is dedicated to this artist’s installation A Computer which Will Solve Every Problem in the World. He used the term “trilogy” to describe his tripartite sculptures, such as one named after “Bel Air” that consists of three 1955 Chevrolet automobiles. You’d die instantly if you were penetrated by the big and thick kilometer-long pole that this artist used to pierce the Earth for his work Vertical Kilometer Zero. The cover photo of Robert Hughes’s book American Vision depicts a work by this artist that was commissioned by the Dia Foundation, and which can only be visited during trips in which parties of six sleep at a nearby cabin. That artwork by him consists of 400 equally-spaced shafts and, despite its name, only very rarely simultaneously illuminates in the middle of the New Mexico desert. For 10 points, name this environmental artist who made The Lightning Field.
tossups.answer: Walter de Maria [or Walter Joseph de Maria]

tossups.question: Mary Lazenby’s story of this man’s life claims he wrote articles for the Maryland Almanac under the name “Philosopher of the Alleghanies.” Early in life, he started a commune called the Sandy Creek Association, which folded after two years. He wrote that “obedience to just laws and subjection to slavery is two different things” in his tract An Impartial Relation of the First Rise. He assumed the name “Tuscape Death” while hiding with Isaac Cox in the Glades, where he amassed a fortune. His pamphlet “Show Yourselves to be Freemen” protested the “oppressive taxation of the Piedmont.” He raised a pole reading “Liberty and No Excise” in Pennsylvania during the Whiskey Rebellion. This Quaker refused to fight as he led followers into battle at Alamance Creek, after which he fled the arrest of Governor William Tryon. For 10 points, name this leader of the Regulator movement in North Carolina.

This mythographer wrote a story in which a member of a race of “Moon-Chewers” wears a mask made of fireflies, and battles against the Bats of the White Baths using “singing tablets.” Another work by this author depicts how the sculptor Ambiastro is killed by his own created art after he flees into a cave. This author of “The Legend of the Crystal Mask” conceived of his homeland as a palimpsest onto which various traditions are “piled on” and “scraped off”. The Mirror of Lida Sal is a work by this mythographer, who wrote a play depicting the palace of the god Kukulcan; that drama appears in a book titled “Legends of” this author’s home country. In a 1967 Nobel Prize lecture, this writer called the Popul Vuh America’s first novel. For 10 points, name this author whose novel about the revolutionary Gaspar Ilom, Men of Maize, includes many references to Guatemalan folklore.

In his autobiography, the designer of this building said making it was abolition, "in the art and craft of architecture, [of] literature in any symbolic form whatsoever." William Curtiss writes that the central square in this building was an “abode of emptiness” likely inspired by Kakuzo Okakura’s Book of Tea. Clerestories and stained glass windows were used to illuminate this building’s greenish and yellowish interior, much like the creator’s previous Larkin Administration Building. The architect's budget for this 1905 building was only 40,000 dollars, though he was able to install a loggia to separate the "community space" from this structure’s other spaces. This building, which was made entirely from reinforced concrete, is five blocks away from the designer's own studio in Oak Park, Illinois. For 10 points, name this Frank Lloyd Wright building made for the Unitarian Universalist church.

In 1977 Charles Blair demonstrated that for complete metric spaces, this theorem is equivalent to the axiom of dependent choice. This theorem is used to prove that pointwise boundedness of a family of continuous linear operators from a Banach space to a normed space entail uniform boundedness; it is also used to prove that a continuous linear map between two Banach spaces is an open map. A way to prove this theorem is by constructing a nested sequence of closed spheres with radii converging to zero, which contains a single point, contradicting the terms of the construction. This theorem’s namesake gives his name to almost-open sets. A corollary of this theorem is that a complete metric space without isolated points is uncountable. A complete metric space cannot be represented as a countable union of nowhere dense sets according to, for 10 points, what man’s “category” theorem?
tossups.answer: Baire category theorem [prompt on category theorem]

tossups.question: This character claims that she learned to say her prayers every night when Death was staring her father in the face since there were “leeches on his neck.” It is suggested that this character, who is in danger of losing her eyesight, use the phrase “bottom of the sea” instead of “depths of the sea” while describing her “whole room.” Earlier this character confesses that she cannot read English, but she still admires an English book because of its opening illustration showing Death and an hourglass. After this character’s death, a man states that his destiny is to be the “thirteenth” at a table. This character’s father obsesses over completing his photographic “great invention,” and the aloofness of her father inspires her to ask her grandfather to kill the title animal as a sacrifice. For 10 points, name this daughter of Hjalmar Ekdal who kills herself in Henrik Ibsen’s The Wild Duck.

A prince of Moldavia nicknamed for this condition sent his minister Tautu to persuade the Ottoman Empire to save his kingdom from Tatar invasions. Another person acquired this condition to save his son, and instituted his city’s custom of requiring anybody proposing a new law to do so wearing a noose, so they could be easily hanged if the law was opposed. In addition to Zaleucus, this condition was given to a man using a tool called the Spoon of Diocles. Bogdan III had an epithet named for this condition, which was also held by a ruler who broke up the “Silver Shields” after they allied with Eumenes against him and Cassander at the Battle of Gabiene. That father of Demetrius “the Besieger” with this epithet was killed by the combined forces of the Diadochi at the Battle of Ipsus. For 10 points, give this feature shared by Philip II of Macedon and Antigonos Monophthalmos.
tossups.answer: having one eye [or One-Eyed, or accept Monophthalmos until read and prompt thereafter]

tossups.question: One of these proteins called PHA-L can be used as a molecular tracer which can cross synapses in anterograde tracing studies. A protein in this non-CD class is responsible for the “rolling adhesion” portion of leukocyte extravasation, especially through interaction with sialyl-LewisX. A legume-derived protein of this type called concanavalin A is used in resins for certain affinity chromatography protocols. Ficolin is one of these proteins which can initiate a variant of the complement pathway similar to the classical pathway; that pathway can also be initiated by one of these proteins called MBL. The most common class of these proteins contains calcium-dependent CLEC [C-lec] domains. Cell membrane staining often uses a dye-conjugated form of one of these proteins named wheat germ agglutinin, which binds to sialic acid and N-acetyl-glucosamine. For 10 points, name this class of proteins which bind to sugars.
tossups.answer: lectins [accept selectins or collectins; prompt on descriptions such as carbohydrate binding proteins before mentioned; prompt on agglutinins]

tossups.question: NOTE: Genre and composer required. One of these works begins with unison cellos and violas introducing a 6/8 principal theme that begins with pickup 16ths on D and E, followed by straight 8ths on F, E, F, D, E, G, F, E, F, which the composer claimed was conceived while waiting for a train. 18 years after it was sent off as a contest entry, the only manuscript of one these works was purchased in a Leipzig bookstore. The third movement scherzo of the sixth of these works imitates a hemiola-heavy dance called a furiant. The finale of the eighth of these works, in G major, begins with a trumpet fanfare conductor Rafael Kubelik described as a “call to the dance.” The D minor seventh of these works includes a Poco adagio slow movement its composer noted was “from the sad years.” The long-lost first of them is often given the title “The Bells of Zlonice.” For 10 points, name these nine works, the last of which, in E minor, features an iconic English horn solo in its Largo second movement.
tossups.answer: symphonies by Antonín Dvořák [accept all answers that mention both Anton(ín) Leopold Dvořák and the notion of symphony or symphonies]

tossups.question: This thinker recommended a balanced budget that included a drachma for the doctor and a talent for the whore in his “Diary of a Profligate,” one of his paignia, or caprices, that includes the now-lost “Praise of Lentil Soup.” This thinker was known as “the door-opener” for his willingness to visit people in their home to talk philosophy. This philosopher described a paradise for adherents of his thought that brought forth “thyme and figs and garlic and loaves of bread,” for which no one fought in the poem Pera. This thinker’s teacher wrote a now-lost text called The Republic which envisions the title location as an anarchist utopia. The students of this husband of Hipparchia of Maroneia included Menippus, Cleomenes, and Zeno of Citium. For 10 points, identify this philosopher from Thebes, who after Diogenes was the foremost champion of Cynicism.

One set of equations for this quantity can be cast in a simple and real form by substituting pseudospin for this quantity. In a non-degenerate ergodic system, this quantity depends only on the energy and has components proportional to the Kronecker delta, while at thermal equilibrium, this quantity is a constant of the motion and thus must commute with the Hamiltonian. For a two-level system, the optical Bloch equations describe the time evolution of this quantity, which is proportional to its commutator with the Hamiltonian according to von Neumann’s theorem. Expectation values of observables can be computed by multiplying the associated operator by this quantity and taking the trace of the result. The coefficients of the orthonormal expansion of the wavefunction in terms of basis states are the components of, for 10 points, what quantity which contains a complete description of a quantum mechanical system?

This author argued that “the modern concept of self-interest is a strange blend… that of Calvin and Luther on the one hand, and on the other, that of progressive thinkers like Spinoza” in a book that conceives of character as productive and non-productive “orientations”. He used the example of K. from Kafka’s The Trial to illustrate the necessity for a “humanistic conscience.” A work by this author has a final section on “The Moral Problem of Today,” and concludes that “we have made ourselves into instruments for purposes outside ourselves, that we experience and treat ourselves as commodities,” and argues that the decision for how the future will be depends on the willingness of people to assume the title attitude. Man For Himself is a work of humanistic psychology by, for 10 points, what German psychologist, who also wrote The Art of Loving and Escape From Freedom?

One member of this family was able to attend Trinity College due to the help of benefactor Julian Carr. As Minister of Foreign Affairs, another member of this family offered to pay $1,000 a month to the pilots who carried out the firebombing plan of Claire Chennault, which he presented to Henry Morgenthau. Mike Cowles relates an incident when a member of this family scratched the face of a lover in revenge. One of them supported building a school at Purple Mountain to house “warphans.” Several members of this family studied at Wesleyan College. One of them married super rich businessman H. H. Kung, and another of them supposedly seduced Wendell Willkie. A saying about three members of this family claimed that “One loved money, one loved power, one loved her country.” For 10 points, give this family of three sisters that included the wives of Sun Yat-Sen and Chiang Kai-Shek.
tossups.answer: Soong [accept Charlie Soong; Soong Tse-ven; T.V. Soong; Soong Ai-ling; Soong Ching-ling; Soong Mei-ling]

tossups.question: This author addressed a “pure spirit” whose “sea is calm, the tempest past” in a poem set in some “deep impenetrable gloom,” near the “secrets of the skies.” A description of this author’s verse as “floating bubbles” and a “silken bubble” that “rides buoyant through the clouds” closes a poem that opens by comparing the Muses to “gossips.” As a critic, this author wrote a 50-volume study called The British Novelists, and wrote Eighteen Hundred and Eleven, a poem criticizing the Napoleonic wars. This author of many Lessons for Children wrote the poem “Dirge” after Rochemont, her husband, attacked her and then committed suicide. Her poem “Washing Day” describe the mundaneness of making breakfast and cleaning clothes and often appears in Romanticism anthologies. For 10 points, name this female poet whose good friends sometimes called her “Anna Letitia.”

The parasol-holding leader of these figures is accompanied by a mongoose which vomits up pearls. Their realm is on Mount Sumeru, between that of the 33 Devas and the Asuras. The first temple sponsored by Prince Shotoku was named for these beings, one of whom allegedly appeared to him while he clashed with the Mononobe clan. The entrances to some temples lead to a hall named for these figures, which are often shown trampling on Jaki demons. The kumbhandas and gandharvas follow these figures, one of whom plays music of his pipa. Their names occupy the corners of a gohonzon. A name meaning “he who hears everything” is attributed to the leader of these lokapalas, an analogue of Kubera known as Vaisravana. They promise to protect those who rule properly in a segment of the Golden Light Sutra. For 10 points, name these Buddhist protector deities, which watch over the cardinal directions.
tossups.answer: four heavenly kings [accept shitennou; accept Sì Dà Tiānwáng; accept four guardian kings; accept chaturmaharaja; accept four great kings; prompt on lokapalas before mentioned; prompt on kings]

tossups.question: In this technique, the data can be analyzed using a hidden Markov model in 3B analysis. Forms of this technique with long acronyms include gSHRIMP, SPDM-phy-mod, and PALMIRA. In one form of this technique, the problem of overlapping PSFs can be avoided by "stochastic switching." One form of this technique minimizes the effects of concentration-dependent scattering by measuring lifetime instead of intensity. When performing this technique, you might set the instrument to collect a z-stack, then add rhodamine B or FITC to your sample. An activation laser is followed by a readout laser in a form of this technique called PALM. The 2014 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded for super-resolved variants of this technique, which can use a confocal setup to excite molecules in a localized region. For 10 points, name this imaging technique which observes singlet-to-singlet electronic relaxations.
tossups.answer: fluorescence microscopy [prompt on super-resolved microscopy or confocal microscopy]

tossups.question: A 1981 Nature article provides an explanation for the appearance of an object on this body which is later confirmed when an Afrikaaner refugee sends the message “LUCY IS HERE” to his uncle. A realization made in this location allows the construction of four towers which connect to an orbital ring. Due to tidal locking, residents of this location can only experience night on the “farside” which leads to their mythologizing their “cold sun”. Mt. Zeus on this body is revealed to be an enormous chunk of diamond ejected during the formation of Lucifer from the core of a planet. The Crew of the Leonov is given the message ALL THESE WORLDS ARE YOURS except this particular world which they are told to attempt no landings on. For 10 points, name this Jovian moon central to the plots of 2010: Odyssey Two, and 2061: Odyssey Three due to its potential for hosting life.

Alice Lyle was beheaded in the aftermath of this conflict. Richard Godfrey guided a failed night attack from Bridgwater in the last battle of this conflict. A dispute between two leaders of this conflict led Andrew Fletcher to kill goldsmith Thomas Hayward Dare in a duel. The wife of the leader of this event sold her jewelry to hire a warship named Heldevenberg. Another uprising designed to support this conflict lost the Battle of Muirdykes and was led by the Earl of Argyll. This event began with a declaration written by Robert Ferguson after the son of Lucy Walter landed at Lyme Regis. More than 100 people were hanged in Taunton castle and almost 1000 were exiled to Barbados in a series of trials after this conflict presided over by George Jeffreys, the “Hanging Judge.” This conflict was ended by John Churchill’s victory at the Battle of Sedgemoor. For 10 points, name this rebellion against James II followed by the Bloody Assizes.
tossups.answer: Monmouth rebellion [or Revolt of the West; West county revolt]

tossups.question: This essay closes with the author quoting Kierkegaard’s “The Present Age” to describe an “all-embracing mirage.” Benedetto Croce’s assertion that “there are too many” Waverley novels is discussed in a part of this essay tracing one of its title concepts to Walter Scott. This essay notes Vance Packard summarized academia’s “sensational findings” under catchy titles like The Hidden Persuaders. First appearing in the 1962 collection Against the American Grain, it savages Thornton Wilder’s Our Town and Hemingway’s The Old Man and the Sea. This essay was written by an author who savaged James Gould Cozzens’ novel By Loved Possessed. Its second title phenomenon seeks to “please the crowd by any means” while pretending to maintain the standards of “High Culture,” but without the authenticity of “lowbrow” experiences. For 10 points, name this essay by Dwight Macdonald.

A character in this novel remembers a time when she fainted in front of The Birth of Venus when she passes out in her boss’s arms after he fires her. A short parody of this novel by Elizabeth Hardwick was published under the pseudonym Xavier Prynne. A woman in this novel is almost raped by the ski jumper Nils when she quotes from “The Shepherdess’s Reply” when he recites “The Passionate Shepherd to His Love.” After taking a woman’s virginity, a man in this novel remarks of his wife that “Betty bled like a pig.” Characters in this book include Lakey, who has a Lesbian affair with a baroness while studying art history in Europe, and Dottie Renfrew, who agrees to be fitted for a diaphragm. This novel ends with the funeral of Kay Strong, who dies after falling from a building at Vassar College. For 10 points, name this novel about a set of female university friends by Mary McCarthy.

bonuses.leadin: According to the book The Tudor Kitchen, Roman emperors would have these birds blinded so that these birds would think it was night and gorge themselves, thereby fattening them for slaughter. For 10 points each:
answers: they are drowned in Armagnac brandy [prompt on drowned; or drowned in brandy;]
parts: Name these French buntings, which have almost been hunted to extinction since they are served in a decadent dish in which they are consumed as diners have their heads wrapped with a napkin as to better savor the aroma.
One of the reasons that ortolans are so flavorful is that they are killed in this very unusual manner. This manner of death requires a liquid that is produced exclusively within a region of Gascony.
Many animal rights activists have compared the treatment of ortolans to the treatment of geese that are used to make this dish, fattened goose liver.

bonuses.leadin: This programming language uses a special data structure called “discriminated unions” that mimics the union type in other languages, but discriminated unions allow for the better handling of heterogeneous data. For 10 points each:
answers: Hindley-Milner [or Damas-Milner or Damas-Hindley-Milner type inference algorithm]
polymorphism [prompt on object-oriented programming or OOP]
parts: Identify this functional programming language for the .NET (“DOT NET”) environment. It is somewhat similar to OCaml.
Like many languages in the ML family, F# guarantees type safety by using this algorithm to guarantee type-compatibility. This algorithm is a refinement of the generically named Algorithm W.
F# has a relatively ad-hoc form of this property, which allows for a single interface to handle many different data types. In C++, templates and operator overloading make this property possible.

bonuses.leadin: This collection includes a nine-part poem written on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory called “State of the Planet.” For 10 points each:
answers: Poet Laureate of the U.S. [or Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this book containing “The Problem of Describing Color” and “The Problem of Describing Trees.” Its title poem describes a typo between action painting and paining, and is named for a phrase found in contracts.

Time and Materials contains some anti-war poetry by this author, whose first two collections were Field Guide and Praise. While teaching at Berkeley, he translated into English the verse of his neighbor Czeslaw Milosz.
For several years in the 1990s, Hass held this position. It has since been held by Charles Simic and Robert Pinsky and is currently held by Juan Felipe Herrera.

bonuses.leadin: This organization consists of 28 members and is currently led by Jean-Claude Juncker. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this institution that oversees daily governance of the EU. It is essentially the executive arm of the EU.

The most influential leader of the European Commission was this Frenchman, who held the office from 1985 to 1995. His namesake report laid the groundwork for the European Economic and Monetary Union, and the Maastricht Treaty was signed during his term.

This director of Princeton’s European Union program and part time music critic is the world’s foremost scholar on European integration, the subject of his book The Choice for Europe. He explains European integration as a result of economic incentives which led states to pool sovereignty to enshrine credible commitments, which he calls intergovernmentalism.

bonuses.leadin: According to Frank Rutter, one of these paintings was originally called Father Comes Home, and given its more popular name for the “sake of a private joke” to “bamboozle” art historians. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this series of paintings that includes What Shall we Do about the Rent? and La Hollandaise. The former may depict a woman in rigor mortis.
Using dubious mitochondrial DNA and the Camden Town Murder series, crime novelist Patricia Cornwell argued that Walter Sickert was actually this 19th-century criminal.

Sickert was a member of the Camden Town group, as was this modernist, who made a self-portrait depicting himself as a “Tyro.” His woodcut Before Antwerp appeared in the second issue of the magazine BLAST.

bonuses.leadin: In a novel from this series, Charles March alienates his family when he stands by his wife despite her having caused a political scandal that harmed his uncle’s reputation. For 10 points each:
answers: Charles Percy Snow [or C. P. Snow or Baron Snow]
Frank Raymond Leavis [or F. R. Leavis]
parts: Name this series of eleven novels narrated by Lewis Eliot that includes Time of Hope and The Conscience of the Rich. A novel in this series coined the phrase “corridors of power.”
This author of Strangers and Brothers gave a lecture in which he argued that Britain placed too much importance on the humanities over mathematics and technology; that lecture is “The Two Cultures.”

C.P. Snow’s “The Two Cultures” was savaged by this critic, who wrote “Snow is in fact portentously ignorant.” His book The Great Tradition analyzes how moral structures inform the novels of Thomas Hardy and Jane Austen.

bonuses.leadin: The Greeks called this city the “City of Zeus,” or Diospolis, noting that it had one hundred gates. FTPE:
answers: Seqenenre Tao [or Seqenera Djehuty-aa or Sekenenra]
parts: Name this city home to the Avenue of Sphinxes and the Opet festival, where the Great Hypostyle Hall built by Seti I is a part of its Temple complex at Karnak.
This last great Theban ruler of the Seventeenth Dynasty, called the Brave, was killed in battle by the king Apophis, after which he was succeeded by his son Kamose.

Seqenenre’s other son Ahmose established the New Kingdom by driving the Hyksos out of this capital city of theirs, which was absorbed into the city of Pi-Ramesses with the advent of the Nineteenth Dynasty.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about lost mythological cities, for 10 points each.
answers: core of the Earth [accept inside the Earth or equivalents]

’Iram of the Pillars [accept either underlined portion; also accept ’Iram Dhaat al-‘Imaad; accept any answer that gets across a city possessing, of, or otherwise characterized by pillars or tentpoles; also ‘Aad or al-’Ahqaaf]
parts: This Breton town ruled by King Gradlon was destroyed when his wicked daughter Dahut gave the key to the dike holding back the sea to a mysterious knight that may or may not have been the Devil.

The French occultist Alexandre Saint-Yves wrote about the secret world of Agartha, a crystal city accessible only to perfected Christians located in this place. Brinsley Le Poer Trench wrote about UFOs in this location in his 1974 book Secret of the Ages.

The Surat al-Fajr asks readers to remember how Allah dealt with this lost Arabian city. It is often identified with other “Atlantises of the Sand” like Ubar and Ma’rib, and its people may have rejected the prophet Hud.

bonuses.leadin: These quantities are those for which the derivative of the Lagrangian with respect to them is zero, meaning that the corresponding generalized momentum is conserved. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this name given to coordinates in Lagrangian mechanics that satisfy the above condition.

When analyzing systems with cyclic coordinates, it is useful to define this function, which obeys the Euler-Lagrange equations for non-cyclic coordinates and obeys Hamilton's equations for cyclic coordinates.
Like the Hamiltonian, the Routhian may be obtained by applying this operation to the Lagrangian. This integral transform is also used to convert between the 4 thermodynamic potentials.

bonuses.leadin: In 2004, David Christopher Lewis claimed to have been visited by this person, thus inspiring his book of alchemy named for this figure. For 10 points each:
answers: Count of Saint Germain [or Comte de Saint Germain]
Alessandro di Cagliostro [or Giuseppe Balsamo or Joseph Balsamo]
parts: Name this alleged 500 year old illegitimate son of a Transylvanian prince. Prince Charles of Hesse-Kassel considered this count as one of the one of the greatest philosophers who ever lived.

Stories of how the Count was the Wandering Jew or actually Francis Bacon are believed by members of this religion founded by Helena Blavatsky. This religion believes in the existence of a group of “Masters” in Tibet.
St. Germain also supposedly met with this Italian count, occultist, and forger, who was imprisoned in the Bastille during the Affair of the Diamond Necklace.

bonuses.leadin: This man supported “low-tax liberalism” and published a book of his proposed programs, entitled A New Beginning, with an introduction by Eugene McCarthy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man, who ran for US President in 1980 alongside wealthy businessman David Koch on the Libertarian Party ticket.

Ed Clark made a name for himself by running for Governor of California in 1978, at which time he opposed the initiative named for this politician, also known as Proposition 6, which would have banned homosexuals from working in public schools.

Clark called himself the “Outlaw” in homage to this Alaskan conman, who duped audiences into thinking they had a chance to win money by selling them a certain substance. This man died at Skagway after fighting Frank Reid in the “Shootout on Juneau Wharf.”

bonuses.leadin: This book argues that rising inequality has led to few benefits for the majority of the country and that it has been sustained and exacerbated by specific government policies. For 10 points each:
answers: Winner Take All Politics: How Washington Made the Rich Richer—and Turned Its Back on the Middle Class
Clinton health care reform plan [accept anything that mentions Clinton and health care; also accept Health Security Act]
parts: Identify this 2010 book of political science, which argues that business investment in politics has led to a state of “politics as organized combat,” which is being lost by the majority of Americans.

This political scientist collaborated with Berkeley’s Paul Pierson on Winner Take All Politics and the later American Amnesia. He is the director of the Institution for Social and Policy Studies at Yale.
Hacker’s first book was a political analysis of this plan, first proposed on the campaign trail in 1992 and eventually sunk partially due to negative ads like the “Harry and Louise” spot.

bonuses.leadin: In one novel by this author, a man named Sonomura cracks a code based on Poe’s The Gold-Bug to figure out where a murder is going to happen, which he then subsequently observes by using peepholes. For 10 points each:
answers: The Makioka Sisters [or Sasameyuki or Light Snow]
parts: Name this author of the recently-translated The Devils in Daylight. Another book by him translated into English in 2016 is The Maids.
Tanizaki’s The Maids retells this novel from the servants’ point of view. This Tanizaki novel is named for a Osaka family whose fortunes have declined.
In 2004, Howard Hibbett translated this novel by Tanizaki into English, which takes the form of alternating diary entries made by Ikiko and her unnamed husband.

bonuses.leadin: Temporal arteritis is sometimes named for these entities, since it is diagnosed by observing this entities on a biopsy. For 10 points each:
answers: giant cells [prompt on large cells or big cells; prompt on multinucleated cells; prompt on syncytia or syncytium; prompt on just cells]
parts: Name this specific type of object, which can also be found in biopsies in sarcoidosis sufferers. They are also seen in an idiopathic condition called Fiedler’s myocarditis.

Reed-Sternberg cells are a class of giant cells found in suffers of this form of lymphoma, which is commonly caused by EBV. Lymphomas are classified as either this type of lymphoma or “non” this type of lymphoma.
Giant cell arteritis is treated using high doses of this class of medications, which are used in the treatment of many inflammatory conditions and include dexamethasone and methylprednisolone.

bonuses.leadin: David Popper’s opus 73 is a collection of 40 études for this instrument, many of which are still used in modern pedagogy. For 10 points each:
answers: harmonics [accept natural harmonics or artificial harmonics]
double stop [or multiple stop or multistop]
parts: Name this instrument featured prominently in Popper’s overall output, which included a Requiem for three of these instruments and orchestra. 12 composers wrote works based on Paul Sacher’s surname for this solo instrument.

Modern cello repertoire often makes heavy use of this technique, in which a string is lightly touched at a node. “Artificial” examples of this technique are notated using a regular notehead on a stopped pitch, and an open diamond on the node to be touched.
Cello works also commonly call for this technique, in which two strings are played at the same time.

bonuses.leadin: This statement considers a “golf course” like landscape as opposed to the “folding-funnel”. For 10 points each:
answers: vibrational circular dichroism [or VCD spectroscopy; prompt on circular dichroism spectroscopy or CD]
parts: Name this "paradox" which notes that due to proteins having many peptide bonds with many possible bond angles, proteins attempting to fold via a random walk would require more time than the age of the universe to achieve their native conformations.

These proteins, as contrasted with fibrous proteins, tend to fold in a manner such that the hydrophobic amino acid residues are packed in the protein's interior, while hydrophilic amino acid residues point to the exterior.

The stability of proteins in various solutions can be observed using this spectroscopic technique, which extends another technique by observing differences in a sample’s absorption of left and right circularly polarized light in the IR range.

bonuses.leadin: Milton Warchoff voiced this character in the premiere of a 1941 operetta, in which he claims “I am the eternal guest, I am way, I am act” after Inkslinger asks him who he really is. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who—due to his enormous size—never actually appears on stage in a Benjamin Britten operetta titled for him.
Cyril Dickinson and James Payton built the enormous concrete and wood statues of Paul Bunyan and Babe the Blue Ox in this state’s city of Bemidji, which claims to be Bunyan’s birthplace.
The Disney animated short Paul Bunyan was directed by this most-senior member of the “Nine Old Men,” who—along with Ub Iwerks and Wilifred Jackson—animated Steamboat Willie.

bonuses.leadin: According to Aristotle, this early playwright formalized the procedures for tragedies in Greek drama, including adding prologues and the chorus. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man. He is sometimes considered to be the first actor and gives his name to an eponym for actors.
Aristotle also claims that Aeschylus was the first to introduce the innovation of adding this kind of character, a second actor who appears on stage with the protagonist.

F. G. Welcker argued that the protagonist actor would have doubled for two roles in Promethus Bound: Prometheus himself, and this other character, who is first shown with Bia and Kratos in the opening.

bonuses.leadin: After leading a Protestant uprising in Chur that resulted in the murder of Pompeius von Planta while he hid in his chimney, this rebel later converted to Catholicism and allied with the Habsburgs. For 10 points each:
answers: Henri de Rohan [accept the Duc de Rohan or Duke of Rohan]
parts: Name this Swiss rebel who plunged Grisons into the anarchic Bunder Wirren or “Confusion of the Leagues.” He was eventually axe-murdered by a man dressed as a bear, allegedly with the same axe use to kill Planta.
The neutrality of the Old Swiss Confederacy was threatened by the Bundner Wirren, a particularly comical theater of this conflict that also included battles at Breitenfeld and Nordlingen.

This ex-Huguenot leader allied with Jenatsch to kick Habsburg forces out of the Valtellina valley. His brother of the same surname, the Duke of Soubise, tried to defend La Rochelle during the 1627 siege.

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher argued for a “new existentialism,” in his preface to a collection of essays titled Having Thought, which he divided into four sections titled “Mind,” “Matter,” “Meaning,” and “Truth.” For 10 points each:
answers: intentionality [do not accept or prompt on “intention” or “intentional”]
parts: Name this late philosopher who coined the term “good old fashioned AI” to describe symbolic AI in his book Artificial Intelligence: The Very Idea.

In a paper on this concept, Haugeland divided it into “authentic,” “ordinary,” and “ersatz” variants, and ascribed the “authentic” type to those scientists who can accept “authentic responsibility.” In a paper titled “Understanding,” Haugeland argued that both Dennett’s and Searle’s idea of this concept was incomplete. Exact noun required.
Haugeland often made use of this philosophical method, which was pioneered by Edmund Husserl. Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel wrote of this process “of Spirit”.
